title: Chelsea Handler had a 'light-bulb moment' about white privilege after playfully slapping a black woman's butt and being told she had no right to do that
text:
Chelsea Handler appeared on the newest episode of the Facebook Watch series "Red Table Talk," and spoke to Jada Pinkett Smith and Adrienne Banfield Norris about her white privilege.

"This black woman was standing up singing a song and I went up to her and I said, 'Oh my God, that was beautiful,' and I hugged her and I slapped her on the butt," the 44-year-old comedian recalled.

Handler went on to say that the woman told her: "Black women have been defined by their hair and their asses for ages. You have no right to touch my body."

Chelsea Handler said that she got a wake-up call about her white privilege after slapping a black woman's butt and being told that her behavior was unacceptable.

"I know you're not going to like this, but I'm going to tell you because it was a learning point," Handler told Jada Pinkett Smith and Adrienne Banfield Norris during the latest episode of their Facebook Watch series, "Red Table Talk," which was released Monday.

"This black woman was standing up singing a song and I went up to her and I said, 'Oh my God, that was beautiful,' and I hugged her and I slapped her on the butt," Handler continued.

In response, Banfield Norris said: "I'm shocked and appalled right now."

Handler went on to say that the woman told her: "Black women have been defined by their hair and their asses for ages. You have no right to touch my body."

Handler said that she was also told that "it's not about your intention, it's about the reception."

The 44-year-old comedian, who recently released a documentary on Netflix called "Hello, Privilege. It's Me, Chelsea," continued: "I smack everybody on the ass. I smack my sisters. I shouldn't be. I shouldn't be smacking anybody on their body.

"It's disrespectful because I'm not taking into account other peoples' experiences. So that was another light-bulb moment," she added.

During the "Red Table Talk" episode, Handler spoke in-depth about her experiences as a white woman. She revealed that she was "rewarded, even in Hollywood, for my bad behavior."

"A black girl would never have gotten her own show for telling celebrities how stupid they were," Handler, who hosted talk shows E!'s "Chelsea Lately" and Netflix's "Chelsea," said.

Handler added that, in retrospect, there were many moments in which she benefited from her whiteness. This included being able to "skirt out of trouble" with law enforcement while her then-boyfriend, a black man, was arrested for possession of weed three times.

"At the time, white privilege didn't occur to me. At the time, I thought, 'I have a great personality and I'm cute, that must be it,'" Handler said. "It didn't occur to me until I had to go back and actually look at that."

description: The comedian appeared on "Red Table Talk" and spoke openly with Jada Pinkett Smith and Adrienne Banfield Norris about a "learning point."
